On 22 April 2017 at 11:09, Fred Mitchell lordalveric@... [neat]
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
>
> Has anyone else taken this functional approach? Or are most implementations
> relying on matrices? Any thoughts as to which approach is better?
>

Hi Fred,

The first thing to note is that the propagation of an array of input
signals through a layer of weights, and summing to produce an output
array - this is conceptually vector-matrix multiplication. How we
choose to do this is an implementation detail, but conceptually we're
all doing vector-matrix multiplication.

In terms of performance, the fastest approach is always going to be to
use hardware acceleration that is designed to do matrix
multiplication. (Or rather, this is always going to be the most
efficient approach, since you could make things very fast by
distributing work out to a great many servers doing slow matrix
multiplication in software instead of hardware.) This is why most AI
type workloads have migrated to GPUs, and why google created the TPU -
at their heart these hardware platforms are providing faster and more
efficient means of performing matrix multiplication.

The hardware matrix multiplication support fundamentally relies on the
data being operated on being in contiguous chucks of memory, since
this allows all of the data to be operated on to be loaded
efficiently, e.g in CPUs this gives good utilisation of the CPU
caches, whereas out of order RAM accesses will cause many cache
misses, and access to RAM is orders or magnitude slower than the
various CPU caches (the L1 to L3 or even level 4 caches).

I'm don't think this necessarily conflicts with the functional
programming approach, but as with non-functional (procedural)
programming models it probably does influence how you arrange data
structures in memory and how you structure the algorithms to operate
on those data structures. Fortunately, matrix multiplication is such a
fundamental operation there is much support out there that can be
leveraged. And we we now have at least three large corporations
throwing lots of money primarily at making matrix multiplication
faster (Nvidia, google, Intel), so things might get even more
interesting in the coming years.

Colin
